node.category: Q0: {What is the way things are?}
Q1: {What about Susie?}

node.surface: Q1.1: {What does Susie do?}
A1.1a: Susie lifts the lid of the abandoned teapot
A1.1b: and swirls the water.

node.category: Q2: {What happens with the teapot after Susie swirls the water?}

node.surface: A2: The teabag sloshes against the sides.

node.category: Q3: {What about the tea?}

node.surface: A3: The tea is cold and bitter,

node.category: Q4: {Does Susie mind the tea being cold and bitter?}

node.surface: A4: but Susie doesn't mind

node.category: Q5: {Why does she not mind?}

node.surface: A5a: because her landlady, Mrs Simpson, normally reuses tea bags.
A5b: Usually, by the time Susie gets home, the tea mostly tastes of chlorine.

node.category: Q1.2: {What does Susie do next?}

node.surface: A1.2a: As she checks Mrs Simpson's calendar,
A1.2b: Susie rubs the place where the elastic cap from work scrunched all day.

node.category: Q6: {What does Susie find in the calender?}

node.surface: A6: A play.

node.category: Q7: {What does the place where the elastic cap from work scrunched all day feel like?}

node.surface: A7: The skin feels puckered and soft, like white and wrinkly fingertips in the bath.

node.category: Q8: {What does Susie's skin feeling puckered and soft make Susie think of?}

node.surface: A8: Her mother used to read beside the clawfoot bathtub her father imported from England.

node.category: Q9: {What did Susie do when her mother read beside the bathtub?}

node.surface: A9: Susie—who wasn't a Susie at all then—would tuck her chin over the edge of the tub and listen.

node.category: Q10: {What would happen after Susie listened for a while?}

node.surface: A10a: The water would go cold.
A10b: Her skin would loose and crinkle.

node.category: Q11: {What about Mrs Simpson?}

node.surface: Q12: {What does Mrs Simpson do?}
A12: Mrs Simpson only makes fresh tea for Mr Johnson next door.

node.category: Q13: {What about the fresh tea Mrs Simpson makes for Mr Johnson?}

node.surface: A13: One cup still contains a moss-smoke slick of whiskey.

node.category: Q1.3: {What does Susie do next?}

node.surface: A1.3a: Susie wipes the rim of the cup with her sleeve
A1.3b: then pours herself some tea.

node.category: Q14: {Can Susie taste the whiskey?}

node.surface: A14a: The whiskey is too dilute to be warm
A14b: but it's nice to know it's there.

node.category: Q1.4: {What does Susie do next?}

node.surface: A1.4a: In the kitchen window, she sees the red elastic mark below her hairline.
A1.4b: She suppresses a sigh
A1.4c: and the air sits heavy in her chest.

node.category: Q15: {How does Susie feel about the air sitting heavy in her chest?}

node.surface: A15: Susie has a knack for ignoring discomfit.

node.category: Q16: {What about Susie's knack for ignoring discomfit?}

node.surface: A16a: It comes in handy at the factory.
A16b: She felt an itch that morning
A16c: but didn't scratch it until after her shift had ended.

node.category: Q17: {What does Susie do before every shift at the factory?}

node.surface: A17: She scrubs her face pink before each shift.

node.category: Q18: {Why does she scrub her face pink?}

node.surface: A18: A single flake of dead skin can ruin a microchip.

node.category: Q19: {What about the factory?}

node.surface: A19: But the factory is also vacuum-dry

node.category: Q20: {How does the factory being vacuum-dry affect Susie?}

node.surface: A21: and she has to moisturise often.

node.category: Q22: {How does she moisturise?}

node.surface: A22: She can only afford sunflower oil.

node.category: Q23: {What is a consequence of using sunflower oil to moisturise?}

node.surface: A23: For the whole day, she breathes the bitter staleness of cooking oil trapped behind the mask.

node.category: Q24: {How does breathing bitter staleness of cooking oil affect Susie?}

node.surface: A24a: Her tongue is always wool.
A24b: In the dust-free factory, her mouth fills with the rat-grey feel of it.

node.category: Q1.5: {What does Susie do next}

node.surface: A1.5: She swallows the tea.

node.category: Q25: {What about Mrs Simpson plans?}

node.surface: A25: Even if it's a matinee, Mr Johnson will insist on dinner.

node.category: Q26: {Who will pay for the dinner Mr Johnson will insist on?}

node.surface: A26: Mrs Simpson will pay.

node.category: Q1.6: {What does Susie do next?}

node.surface: A1.6a: Susie climbs the stairs to Mrs Simpson's room
A1.6b: and tries the door.

node.category: Q27: {What about the door to Mrs Simpson's room?}

node.surface: A27: It's locked.

node.category: Q28: {What does Susie do about the locked door?}

node.surface: A28: In the shower room Susie shares with the taxi driver she's never met, she finds hairpins strewn around the sink.

node.category: Q29: {Where do the hairpins come from?}

node.surface: A29: She's not sure if they are Mrs Simpson's or if the taxi driver has female guests.

node.category: Q30: {What about guests?}

node.surface: A30: Guests aren't allowed, of course,

node.category: Q31: {Does Susie think the taxi driver has guests that are not allowed?}

node.surface: A31: but Susie doesn't know enough about the taxi driver to know if he's the type to flaunt the rules.

node.category: Q1.7: {What does Susie do next?}

node.surface: A1.7: She picks the lock to Mrs Simpson's room.

node.category: Q32: {Has Susie been to Mrs Simpson's room before?}

node.surface: A32: Susie's in there every week to clean,

node.category: Q32: {Is Susie alone in Mrs Simpon's room when she is in there to clean?}

node.surface: A32: but only under Mrs Simpson's watchful eye.

node.category: Q33: {Why was Susie always watched by Mrs Simpson?}

node.surface: A33a: Mrs Simpson doesn't trust people.
A33b: She especially doesn't trust immigrants.

node.category: Q34: {How does Mrs Simpson's distrust towards immigrants relate to Susie?}

node.surface: A34: Susie wonders why Mrs Simpson decided to live with two

node.category: Q35: {Who is the other immigrant?}

node.surface: A35: (Susie knows the taxi driver is an immigrant

node.category: Q36: {Why does Susie know the taxi driver is an immigrant?}

node.surface: A36: because Mrs Simpson often says: ‘Oh, I suppose you two are exceptions to the rule',

node.category: Q37: {What is the rule?}

node.surface: A37: the rule being that immigrants impact everything in Mrs Simpson's life and society and the country negatively).

node.category: Q38: {What is Mrs Simpson's reason to choose immigrants as tennants?}

node.surface: A38a: Susie suspects it has something to do with the small rooms and the black mould that spots the wallpaper.
A38b: Also, in her interview for the room, Mrs Simpson clearly stated she was looking for someone who works during the day.

node.category: Q39: {Why was Mrs Simpson looking for someone who works during the day?}

node.surface: A39a: She already had someone who worked during the night.
A39b: If she fell and broke her hip at midnight, she needed to know she could rely on the person to be in.

node.category: Q40: {What does Susie think about Mrs Simpson needing to rely on the person to be in at midnight?}

node.surface: A40: Susie thinks this sort of responsibility might put people off.

node.category: Q41: {What about Mrs Simpson's room?}

node.surface: A41a: Like the factory, Mrs Simpson's room tries hard to be dust-free and clean,
A41b: but it smells of urine.

node.category: Q42: {Why does the room smell of urine?}

node.surface: A42: Susie suspects Mrs Simpson wets the bed and doesn't know.

node.category: Q43: {What about going to the bathroom at the factory?}
Q43.1: {What about Susie and going to the bathroom?}

node.surface: A43.1: Susie can go a whole twelve-hour shift without the bathroom.

node.category: Q43.2: {What about Susie's co-workers?}

node.surface: A43.2: Some of the others use plastic bottles under the conveyor belt and inside their suits.

node.category: Q44: {Why do Susie's co-workes use plastic bottles?}

node.surface: A44a: The company allows for five-minute breaks every three hours,
A44b: but it takes longer than that just to come back through decontamination.

node.category: Q1.8: {What does Susie do next}

node.surface: A1.8: Susie hangs her towel on the radiator, curling her fingers around the warm bars.

node.category: Q45: {What does Susie see?}

node.surface: A45a: Along the shelves are glass jars of coloured salts,
A45b: and powders,
A45c: and liquids.

node.category: Q46: {What does she do with those jars?}

node.surface: A46: She opens a jar and inhales.

node.category: Q47: {What does Susie smell as she opens a jar?}

node.surface: A47: Lavender.

node.category: Q48: {What does the smell of Lavender make Susie think of?}

node.surface: A48: She remembers her mother's long dark hair, the thin stripes of grey.

node.category: Q49: {What happens when Susie touches the jar's contents?}

node.surface: A49: The flat crystals dissolve into oil that disappears in her dry palms.

node.category: Q46: {What does Susie do with those jars?}

node.surface: A46a: She sprinkles some into the water.
A46b: Not as many as she would like, but some.

node.category: Q1.9: {What does Susie do next}

node.surface: A1.9: She presses her nose to the clean towels stacked on the shelf.

node.category: Q47: {what does Susie smell when she presses her nose to the clean towels?}

node.surface: A47: Washing powder and sunshine.

node.category: Q48: {What does the smell make Susie think of?}

node.surface: A48: Her own towel smells of old socks and the unwashed skin scent that leaks under the door of the taxi driver's room.

node.category: Q1.10: {What does Susie do next}

node.surface: A1.10: She waves her hands through the steam of the running tap.

node.category: Q49: {What does the steam of the running tap make her think of?}

node.surface: A49: In the factory, the conveyor belts move with constant speed, greased silent.

node.category: Q50: {What is the consequence of this constant speed while being silent?}

node.surface: A50a: If she's thinking of something else, like the seamless way her mother poured tea or her father's whiskers above her mother's delicate cups, she will think the belt has stopped.
A50b: She will think the microchips are standing still
A50c: and the only sound is her circling, oily breath.

node.category: Q51: {What happens when Susie does think of something else?}

node.surface: A51a: Then she'll hear the sticky peel of a defect from further along the belt
A51b: and she'll remember where she is.

node.category: Q1.11: {What does Susie do next}

node.surface: A1.11a: She slips into the water.
A1.11b: She inhales.
A1.11c: She prepares for the lavender memory of her mother's cheek against her forehead.

node.category: Q52: {Does Susie remember the lavender memory of her mother's cheek agains her forehead?}

node.surface: A52: But all she smells is chlorine and the wet-dogness of her towel.

node.category: Q53: {What does Susie think of the smell of chlorine?}

node.surface: A53: Still, she resolves to enjoy it.

node.category: Q1.12: {What does Susie do next}

node.surface: A1.12a: The water slinks past her skin, touches her lips.
A1.12b: She licks them dry.
A1.12c: She imagines her mother's perfectly brewed tea.
A1.12d: She takes a deep breath.
A1.12e: Exhales.

node.category: Q1.13: {What will Susie do after taking a bath?}

node.surface: A1.13: After, she will change Mrs Simpson's sheets,

node.category: Q54: {What is the purpose of Susie changing the sheets?}

node.surface: A54: and hopefully, Mrs Simpson will never know.
